intro: Gilia propinqua, commonly known as the plains gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant typically grows in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils, often in arid or semi-arid regions. It produces showy, five-petaled flowers in shades of pink, purple, and white, which bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant is adapted to dry conditions and has hairy stems and leaves to reduce water loss.
